column4: Rembrandt Since the discovery of this painting in the early twentieth century there has been a discussion about its attribution. Rosenberg rejected an attribution to Rembrandt, regarding it as an old copy after Rembrandt (Rosenberg 1956, no. 354). Bauch proposed an attribution to Gerrit Dou (Bauch 1960, p. 228-229; Bauch 1966, p. 48). In 1982 the RRP listed the painting in the B-category of the Corpus with paintings of which an attribution to Rembrandt cannot be accepted nor rejected (Corpus of Rembrandt Paintings 1982-2015, vol. 1 (1982), no. B 2). Tümpel regarded it as a work by an early follower of Rembrandt (Tümpel 1986, no. A 28). Since the restoration of the painting in 1994, removing the eighteenth century additions and overpainting, most art historians agree on an attribution to Rembrandt (see for instance: Van Straten/Moerman 2005, p. 30; Weller et al. 2011, no. 2; Corpus of Rembrandt Paintings 1982-2015, vol. 6 (2015), no. 3).

column5: The vision of Daniel
column21: art dealer Peter Anthony Motteux, London (England) 1714 - Probably identical with an entry in the sale catalogue "'Motteux's Sale of Pictures": "Daniel's Vision of the Ram. Rembrandt" (London 1714-1717, no. 41). Peter Anthony Motteux was an art dealer in London and sold the paintings in his own auction Room in the Little Piazza in Covent-Garden, London. private collection Joshua Reynolds (Sir), London In the catalogue of Ralph’s Exhibition in April 1791 the painting was described as in the collection of Sir Joshua Reynolds (London 1791, no. 48). At that time Reynolds valued the painting at 600 guineas (Farington 1978-1984, vol. 2, p. 316).Special status  1792 private collection Lady Inchiquin by descent from her uncle Sir Joshua Reynolds 1792 - 1795 In 1795 the collection of Reynolds had to be sold at auction to pay off Lord Inchiquin's debts. With the help of the artist Joseph Farington (1747-1821) a minimum price for the most important paintings was determined (Farington 1978-1984), vol. 2, p. 299, 311, 313).The present painting did not reach this minimum price and was, togeher with "Susanna and the elders" (Gemäldegalerie SMB, cat. no. 828 E), bought back by the heirs via someone called Wilson (Farington 1978-1984), vol. 2, p. 316). private collection Charles Offley 1795 - 1796 On 22 March 1795 the present painting, together with "Susanna and the elders", was sold to Charles Offrey (1747-1821) through his brother-in-law Joseph Farington (together for 280 guineas, Farington 1978-1984, vol. 2, p. 318). private collection Joseph Berwick, Hallow Park 1796 - 1798 On 31 January 1796 the present painting and the "Susanna and the elders" was sold to Joseph Berwick (d. 1798) through Joseph Farington for 350 guineas. At that time the residence of Berwick was under construction, so the paintings were temporary located in the house of Farington (Farington 1979-1984, vol. 2, p. 485-486, 488). The painting must still have been there in the autumn of 1797. Farington showed the painting to different persons and the painter Richard Smirke borrowed it from Farington to reproduce a copy (Farington 1978-1984, vol. 2, p. 541; vol. 3 p. 889). private collection Mary Berwick, The Rhydd by descent from her father Joseph Berwick. Mary Berwick was married to Sir Anthony Lechmere, 1st Baron (1766-1849), Rhydd Court, Hanley Castle (Worcestershire). 1798 - private collection Sir Edmund Hungerford Lechmere (2nd Baron), The Rhydd by descent from his mother Lady Mary Lechemere (1769-1820) and his father Sir Anthony Lechmere (1766-1849 - 1856 private collection Sir Edmund Lechmere, The Rhydd by descent from Sir Edmund Hungerford Lechmere, 2nd Baron (1792-1856) 1856 - 1883 During his England-journey from March until June 1879 Wilhelm Bode visited the collection of Lechmere on 30 Mai 1879. He described the painting in his travel report (SMB-ZA, IV/NL Bode 0054, p. 54).In 1882 Sir E.H. Lechmere lent "The vision of Daniel" to the "Worcestershire Exhibition" (Worcester 1882, no. 68). In 1883 the present painting, together with "Susanna and the elders", was on loan from the collection of Sir E.H. Lechmere to the Royal Academy for the exhibition: "Exhibition of works by the Old Masters and by deceased Masters of the British School" (London 1883, no. 234). The paintings were noticed by Wilhelm Bode (Gaethgens/Paul 1997, vol. 1, p. 177), but he must have seen them already in 1879. During his England-journey from March until June 1879 Bode visited the Lechmere collection (Stockhausen 2000, p. 156). art dealer Charles Sedelmeyer, Paris (France) , inv./cat.nr 136 (catalogue 1898) 1883 private collection Oscar Hainauer, Berlin 1883 - 1884 In 1883 Oscar Hainer bought the present painting and "Susanna and the elders" from the art dealer Sedelmeyer. In the same year he gave the paintings on loan to the Gemäldegalerie. On 24 March 1883 the Gemäldegalerie decided to purchase the paintings for 260.000 francs. In April 1884 the acquisition of the paintings was laid down in a contract between de museum and Oscar Hainauer. Only in 1886/1887 the Gemäldegalerie paid Hainauer 214.000 Mark for the paintings (Stockhausen 2000, p. 75, 308, no. 539).Gemäldegalerie der Königliche Museen zu Berlin, Berlin , inv./cat.nr III/372 (inventory 1884) 1884 - In 1904 the painting was transferred to the Kaiser Friedrich Museum (at present Bodemuseum). In the period from September 1941 – September 1942 the painting, together with other works of art of the Gemäldegalerie, was located in the flak towers of Leitturm Berlin-Friedrichshain. From 11 March - 7 April 1945 the paintings were transported from Berlin to the salt mines of Kaiseroda-Merkers, where the works of art were stored until they were discovered and confiscated by the Americans. On 17 April 1945 they moved the works of art, including the painting, to the Reichsbank in Frankfurt am Main. From 20 August-31 August 1945 the works of art were removed from the Reichsbank and temporary stored in the Central Art Collecting Point Wiesbaden, located in Landesmuseum Wiesbaden (inventory number WIE 0/142). The present painting, together with more than 200 other works of art of the Gemäldegalerie, moved from 20 November until 7 December 1945 to The National Gallery in Washington (Box nr. 12 (295) (18); Image no. 68 (Farmer 2002, p. 186)). Most probably the painting was transported back to Wiesbaden in April 1949. On 20 April 1949 the American trusteeship was handed over to the state Hessen. On 11 January 1956 the works of art of the Berlin Gemäldegalerie officially came within the escrow of Berlin and the return of the works of art from Wiesbaden to Berlin began.The collection of paintings was located in the Gemäldegalerie in Dahlem (Berlin West) until 1998.Gemäldegalerie (Staatliche Museen zu Berlin), Berlin , inv./cat.nr 828 F From 1998 onwards the collection of old master paintings of the Staatliche Museen is located in the Gemäldegalerie at the Kulturforum.

column4: Nicolaes Berchem Veilingcatalogus 2012: 'Annemarie Stefes, Verfasserin des in Vorbereitung befindlichen Werkverzeichnisses von Nicolaes Berchem, bestätigt die Zuschreibung an den Künstler (Schreiben vom 12. September 2005, in Kopie vorhanden). Ihr zufolge handelt es sich hierbei um die Vorzeichnung für die im Gegensinn erscheinende Radierung von Cornelis Visscher (Hollstein 68). Stil und Technik verbinden die Zeichnung mit zwei weiteren Blättern in Leiden (Kupferstichkabinett der Universität) und einer Zeichnung mit unbekanntem Standort (Fotoarchiv RKD), die die Vorlagen zu Visschers Radierungen aus derselben Folge (Hollstein 69 und 70) sind. Als Entstehungszeit vermutet Annemarie Stefes die Jahre 1657-1658. - Geschlossener Einriss, etwas fleckig, vereinzelte hinterlegte Fehlstellen.'

column5: Tombeau de saint-Lazare : Sainte Marthe
column21: Autun ; musée Rolin
column39: Sculpture en calcaire blanc représentant une sainte Marthe : monobloc, vêtue d'une tunique, voile et manteau, portant un mouchoir de sa main gauche à son visage. Le voile est traité dans un drapé simple en volutes, puis les plis retombent en soulignant les épaules. Le bord du voile est orné d'un liseret sur lequel est creusé au foret une suite de trous. La tête de Marthe s'avance par rapport à l'axe de la sculpture, le dos est plat et lisse. Inscription sur pan du vêtement du bras droit : S MARTHA

column21: Besançon ; musée des beaux-arts et d'archéologie
column39: Au bas d'un escalier monumental, Lazare pauvrement vêtu et malade est assis, accoudé à un piédestal surmonté d'un sphinx alors que trois chiens lèchent ses plaies; derrière lui, plusieurs serviteurs indifférents à son sort transportent de somptueux mets en direction du palais, où certains convives se dirigent alors que d'autres sont déjà sur le balcon

A 138). private collection Charles Emmanuel III of Sardinia, Turijn 1741 - 1802 The bulk of the collection of Eugen von Savoyen, including the present painting, was sold to Charles Emmanuel III of Sardinia in 1741 by Prince Eugene's niece and heir Maria Anna Victoria of Savoy-Carignano-Soissons. A 138) private collection Hugh Richard Arthur Grosvenor (2nd Duke of Westminster), Grosvenor House (London) by descent - 1913 sold in 1913 (Corpus of Rembrandt Paintings 1982-2015, Vol. 3 (1989), no.
